Description: Limestone stela fragment: on the upper portion of a round-topped stela the figures of Amenhotep I and Ahmose-Nefertari are carved in sunk relief. They are enthroned before an altar on which rests a water-pot and other offerings. All texts are incised. The lower portion of this stela is lost. The upper surviving part is damaged along the edges and scratched and gouged on the surface. There are no traces of colour.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Thebes (historic - Upper Egypt), Probably Deir el-Medina
Curator's comments: Bibliography: The British Museum, 'A guide to the Egyptian galleries (Sculpture)' (London, 1909), 101 (no. 349); J. Černy. ‘Bulletin de l’Institut Français d’Archéologie Orientale’ 27 (Cairo, 1927), 165, fig. 1; B. Porter & R. Moss, 'Topographical Bibliography of Ancient Egyptian Hieroglyphic Texts, Reliefs and Paintings' I (2) (Oxford: Clarendon Press), ii, 736.
Bibliographic references: Hall 1922 / Hieroglyphic texts from Egyptian stelae, etc., in the British Museum, Part 6. (pl.34)
Bierbrier 1993 / Hieroglyphic texts from Egyptian stelae, etc., in the British Museum, Part 12. (Pl.54-55)

Condition: The lower portion of this stela is lost. The upper surviving part is damaged along the edges and scratched and gouged on the surface. There are no traces of colour.
Associated names: Named in inscription & portrayed: Amenhotep I
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Somerset Lowry-Corry, 2nd Earl of Belmore
